title: in Google maps spesso l'uso di ctrl + mouse non funziona
content: Non sono sicuro ai aver scelto la categoria giusta, comunque nel titolo ho detto appunto che usando Google maps con Firefox (a differenza di quanto accade con Vivaldi o Falkon) spesso, 9 volte su 10, l'uso di ctrl + mouse non funziona: posso solo ingrandire o rimpicciolire l mappa, ma non "spostarla" tenendo premuto ctrl e cercando di trascinarla a destra o a sinistra o sopra o sotto.
creator: web89

title: con enter (invio) nella casella di ricerca non si avvia la ricerca ma si va a capo
content: L'ho detto nel titolo: con enter (invio) nella casella di ricerca non si avvia la ricerca ma si va a capo. Invece mi pare che un volta anche in Firefox enter, dopo aver digitato che cosa cercare non comportava un "a capo" nella casella di ricerca (che per lo più non ha alcun senso), ma l'avvio della ricerca, che ora richiede l'uso del mouse sull'icona della lente di ingrandimento a destra.
creator: web89

title: My ITTP website for JBT from Haryana is not working properly on Mozilla Firefox
content:
Hello Mozilla Support Team, I manage the official website of ITTP, which provides information about our JBT from Haryana JBT from Haryana course. Recently, I noticed that the website isn’t working properly on the Mozilla Firefox browser. Some pages load slowly, and certain design elements like buttons and banners are not displaying correctly, even though the site works fine on Chrome and Edge.

I’ve already cleared cache, checked extensions, and verified that our SSL and JavaScript files are properly configured. Still, the issue continues on Firefox across multiple devices.

Could this be related to compatibility settings, outdated scripts, or browser-specific rendering issues? I’d really appreciate any guidance or troubleshooting steps to ensure the ITTP site runs smoothly for users searching for JBT from Haryana information.

Thank you for your help!
creator: ittpbed02

title: Is Mozilla aware that newtab@mozilla.org.xpi might be corrupting other profiles?
content:
A few days ago I got PRIME working after struggling for a few months with it. When I rebooted, Firefox loaded my windows but no tabs, and had some very strange graphical glitches. However, it loaded everything in safe mode, then nothing again in normal mode, back and forth. It's taken me days to track this one down, but deleting the file `~/.mozilla/firefox/<profile>/extensions/newtab@mozilla.org.xpi` enabled me to load my session again without having to copy-paste tons of tab URLs or reinstall and reconfigure all my extensions, etc.

Would have been a nightmare, and after the debacle with Exposé wiping nearly 1000 open tabs, I've never quite trusted Firefox. Since then Chromium has wiped > 600 _thrice_ though so I'm seriously considering switching back to Firefox... if it can respect my data and stop suggesting a corrupt profile should be fixed by a "refresh" (aka "delete all your data since we treated it poorly").

Anyway, the file timestamp is 5 Nov (2 days ago), and correlates with a system update I did around the same time. I'm on Arch Linux which is rolling release, so I might serve as a dead canary to warn that something should get fixed now before it hurts more users.
creator: Iiridayn

title: Trojan.JS.Agent.exz found inside Firefox Cache folder by Kaspersky
content:
Kaspersky just found this hidden in the Firefox cache folder and the funny part is that I don't even use Firefox that much. I didn't visit any sites on this particular Firefox except Facebook. So, what sort of malware is this? A Trojan stealer or a dropper of some sort? I am running a Full Scan for now and I have uninstalled all the browsers incl Firefox, Chrome. Detection name: Trojan.JS.Agent.exz

The details of Detection: Event: Object deleted User: DEMON-SLAYER-2\....... User type: Initiator Application name: avpui.exe Application path: C:\Program Files (x86)\Kaspersky Lab\Kaspersky 21.22 Component: File Anti-Virus Result description: Deleted Type: Trojan Name: Trojan.JS.Agent.exz Precision: Exactly Threat level: High Object type: File Object name: 2309DFD956392BDFD0C84CA455FF6426B6B0FA9F Object path: C:\Users\......\AppData\Local\Mozilla\Firefox\Profiles\i2607jtb.default-release-1739822052193\cache2\entries MD5 of an object: 6FEC3D1DC6D1802AEADC4F8611A9F326

Since this is a Trojan, can this be Dangerous? I scanned it in virustotal and 33 engines were saying malware.

Virustotal link: https://www(dot)virustotal(dot)com/gui/file/2cee43e2e59ade158bfe5b124c07e9e45b7a378e379a8be8bb3272b10cf344e2/detection
creator: rounakr94

title: Recovering Tabs and Bookmarks after motherboard replacement
content:
I recently had an issue with my computer screen. The computer itself worked fine, but the screen needed to be replaced. Stupidly, I went to the Bestbuy I bought it from to use the warranty for repair. They sent it out, I just got it back, and it says they replaced my motherboard for whatever reason. My downloads and such back up automatically, but because I didn't expect them to do something so drastic, I neglected to create a backup key for my tabs and bookmarks. Obviously, they're all gone now. Is there any way I could possibly get any of this back, or am I screwed out of luck because those morons made a drastic decision that did not need to be made? I'll apologize ahead of time for my lack of technical know-how.

Thanks
creator: Bolsh44
